en.sc1: Let's look at an example to see the difference between shallow and deep copying.
en.sc2: First let's create an Employee named Sam which is referenced by firstEmployee.
en.sc3: Then create an shallowCopy Employee object which refers to the firstEmployee object.
en.sc4: Now, using setName(), update the Employee object's name as "John", which shallowCopyEmployee is pointing to.
en.sc5: If you print out the name of firstEmployee, you will see that the name of the Employee is now "John," not "Sam.".
en.sc6: Now, we create an Employee object, secondEmployee. Set the name of secondEmployee as "Patrice."
en.sc7: Then we create an Employee object, deepCopyEmployee.
en.sc8: After that, copy the name of secondEmployee and set the name as deepCopyEmployee's name. So you deep-copied secondEmployee.
en.sc10: Finally, if you print the name of secondEmployee, it is stil "Patrice" and changing deepCopyEmployee's name did not effect any of secondEmployee's values.
